title: Stop search results from dynamically resorting

labels.name: feature-request
labels.description: Request for new features or functionality

milestone.title: Backlog Candidates
milestone.description: Work that is not yet accepted for the Backlog. We wait for the community to weigh in.

body: Type: Feature Request Easily my most hated VS.Code behavior - searching across my project is a NIGHTMARE because the list is constantly resorting. My item will show up almost immediately, but before I can even select it, it's been resorted off the page. I honestly don't see why people rave about VS.Code so much (over VS.Net) given stuff like this - it is EXTREMELY frustrating to use. Why would you not have a mode where you just append results to THE END OF THE LIST!??!??!? Can you at least provide a use case to where the current behavior is actually helpful (am I supposed to click Search and then go get a coffee until it finishes? If so, how do I know that it's done and won't resort again as I scroll the list)? It is just so annoying and tedious this way that it feels like it was never actually tested in the real world. title: Markdown Image Hover Preview broken for file paths exceeding 259

labels.name: bug

labels.name: help wanted
labels.description: Issues identified as good community contribution opportunities

milestone.title: Backlog

body:
Type: Bug While editing a markdown file, hovering the cursor over the link to an image should popup a preview of the image. However, if the path to the image exceeds 259 characters the preview does not appear in the popup, and instead displays the broken image link icon. The markdown preview window renders the image regardless of path length. Steps to reproduce 1. Create a markdown file and open in the VSCode editor. 2. Insert a link to an image file where the path is over 259 characters. 3. Hover your curser over the link, and the broken link icon appears (see first image below). 4. Open the markdown preview pane and note that the image is displayed as expected (see first image below). 5. shorten the path of the source image to be 259 characters or less. 6. Hover your curser over the link, and image preview appears as expected (see second image below). Question: How can I change the font size in all areas of Visual Studio Code, including the editor, terminal?

The **editor.fontsize** setting adjusts the font size within the editor.
The **terminal.integrated.fontSize** setting changes the font size in the integrated terminal.
This **window.zoomLevel** setting controls the zoom level of the entire Visual Studio Code interface.
```json

title: Fix accessibility issues with confirmation widget, add command to focus it directly if present, announce none if not present
body:
https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/35b0e056-a52c-4cb7-ae23-104bd719a9a6

Screen reader users might miss chat confirmation dialogs when they're focused in the editor, making it difficult to interact with chat agents that require user confirmation. This PR adds a new accessibility command to help users discover and interact with these confirmation dialogs.

## New Feature

Adds a new command **"Announce Chat Confirmation Status"** with keyboard shortcut `Alt+A` that:

- **Announces confirmation status** to screen readers using `aria.alert()`
- **Counts active confirmations** and reports the number of actions needed
- **Auto-focuses the first confirmation dialog** for immediate interaction
- **Provides feedback** when no confirmations are pending

## Implementation

The command scans the current chat session's view model to detect active confirmations by checking for `content.kind === 'confirmation' && !content.isUsed`. When confirmations are found, it announces:

- "Chat confirmation required. X action(s) needed." (focuses first dialog)
- "No chat confirmation required." (when none pending)

## Accessibility Documentation

The new command is documented in the Chat Accessibility Help dialog alongside other chat accessibility commands, making it discoverable to users who rely on screen readers.

## Usage

Users can press `Alt+A` while in a chat session or invoke "Announce Chat Confirmation Status" from the Command Palette (F1). The command is context-aware and only available during active chat sessions.

## Files Changed

- `src/vs/workbench/contrib/chat/browser/actions/chatAccessibilityActions.ts` (new file)
- `src/vs/workbench/contrib/chat/browser/chat.contribution.ts` (registration)
- `src/vs/workbench/contrib/chat/browser/actions/chatAccessibilityHelp.ts` (documentation)

The implementation follows established VS Code patterns for accessibility and makes minimal, surgical changes to the existing codebase.

Fixes #261864.
Fixes https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/262502

title: Add accessibility headers to chat list items for screen reader navigation
body:
This change restores headers to chat list items specifically for accessibility purposes, addressing the navigation challenges faced by screen reader users after headers were recently removed from the chat interface.

## Problem

Screen reader users rely on heading navigation (pressing "H" to jump between headings) to efficiently navigate between chat requests and responses in browse mode. When headers were removed from chat list items, this navigation method became unavailable, forcing users to navigate through many individual elements using arrow keys, which is tedious and inefficient.

## Solution

Added accessibility-focused headers that are:
- **Semantically correct**: Uses H3 elements with `aria-level="3"` for proper heading structure
- **Visually hidden**: Headers are completely invisible using standard screen reader hiding techniques (absolute positioning, clipping, etc.) but remain accessible to assistive technology
- **Contextually meaningful**: Dynamic text content provides clear identification:
  - "Chat Request" for user requests
  - "Chat Response from [Agent Name]" for agent responses with agent information
  - "Chat Response" for generic responses

## Implementation Details

- Added `accessibilityHeader: HTMLElement` to the `IChatListItemTemplate` interface
- Created headers in `renderTemplate()` with comprehensive CSS hiding rules
- Implemented dynamic content updates in `renderChatTreeItem()` based on item type
- Added robust CSS rules using multiple hiding techniques for cross-browser compatibility
- Maintained complete backward compatibility with no visual design changes

## Testing

- Created comprehensive test suite to verify header presence and content
- Built interactive demo showing functionality with simulated screen reader navigation
- Validated semantic structure and accessibility compliance

The change follows WCAG guidelines for hidden but accessible content and provides screen reader users with the same efficient navigation capabilities they had before headers were removed, without affecting the visual design.

Fixes #261862.

title: Fix repeated "Made changes" messages in chat accessible view
body:
The accessible view was showing repeated "Made changes." messages when multiple file edits were applied in chat agent mode, causing repetitive screen reader announcements.

## Problem

When a chat response contained multiple `textEditGroup` or `notebookEditGroup` items, the `partsToRepr` method in `chatModel.ts` was adding "Made changes." for each individual edit group. Since the accessible view calls `response.toString()`, users would hear "Made changes. Made changes. Made changes." repeated multiple times.

![Accessible view showing repeated "Made changes" messages](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/dae804eb-f32b-4814-88fe-e7cb275df053)

## Solution

Modified the `partsToRepr` method to consolidate multiple edit groups into a single "Made changes." message:

- Skip individual edit groups during processing to avoid duplication
- Track edit groups after the last clear operation (handles `clearToPreviousToolInvocation`)
- Add a single consolidated "Made changes." message at the end when edit groups are present
- Preserve all existing functionality for non-edit content

## Result

- Multiple edit groups → Single "Made changes." message (was: multiple repetitions)
- No edit groups → No "Made changes." message (unchanged)
- Clear operations properly reset edit group tracking
- Consistent with existing UI patterns for edit consolidation

The fix ensures screen reader users hear "Made changes." only once regardless of how many files were edited, significantly improving the accessibility experience.

Fixes #261861.

title: Use problem matcher events more directly for task agent problems
body:
This PR addresses the issue where task agent tools were indirectly accessing problem matcher results through the marker service instead of using the more direct approach of monitoring task events.

## Problem

The existing implementation in `getProblemsForTasks()` was querying the marker service with `markerService.read({ owner: matcher.owner })` after tasks completed, rather than using the problem matcher events that are already being fired by the terminal task system.

## Solution

Implemented a more direct approach by:

1. **Created `TaskProblemMonitor` class** that listens directly to task events:
   - `TaskEventKind.ProblemMatcherEnded` - uses the `hasErrors` flag from `ITaskProblemMatcherEndedEvent` directly
   - `TaskEventKind.ProblemMatcherFoundErrors` - marks tasks as having errors when problems are found
   - Maintains a real-time mapping of task IDs to error states

2. **Enhanced existing functions** to support event-driven problem detection:
   - `getTaskProblemsWithEvents()` - hybrid approach using events when available, falling back to markers
   - `pollForOutputAndIdle()` - enhanced to accept optional `TaskProblemMonitor`
   - Updated entire call chain from task tools through to polling functions

3. **Maintained backward compatibility** - all new parameters are optional, so existing code continues to work unchanged

## Key Benefits

- **More direct access**: Uses task events instead of post-hoc marker service queries
- **Real-time monitoring**: Tracks problem state as events fire from the terminal task system
- **Event-driven approach**: Leverages the existing `ITaskProblemMatcherEndedEvent` infrastructure
- **Better performance**: Avoids repeated marker service queries

The solution provides the "pointer to [problem diagnostics] that is valid until they are disposed" as mentioned in the issue, by monitoring the actual problem matcher lifecycle events from the terminal task system.

Fixes #261866.

title: Fix focus restoration after Alt+F1 accessibility help in chat
body:
When users press Alt+F1 from a chat input to open accessibility help and then press Escape to dismiss it, focus was not being restored to the chat input for certain chat types (`quickChat`, `editsView`, and `agentView`).

## Root Cause

The `AccessibleContentProvider` in `chatAccessibilityHelp.ts` had a focus restoration callback that only handled `panelChat` and `inlineChat` types. The missing chat types had no focus restoration logic, causing focus to be lost when the accessibility help was dismissed.

## Solution

Added focus restoration logic for the missing chat types by using the existing `widgetService.lastFocusedWidget?.focusInput()` pattern that's used elsewhere in the codebase. This ensures that when accessibility help is dismissed via Escape, focus returns to the appropriate chat input.

The fix maintains existing behavior for `panelChat` and `inlineChat` while adding proper focus restoration for:
- `quickChat`
- `editsView` 
- `agentView`

Fixes #261859.

title: VSCode only inconsistent with `mcp.json` schema
body:
Lots of MCP clients follow the same JSON schema for configuring MCP servers:

```json
{
	"mcpServers": {
		"test-mcp": {
			"type": "stdio",
			"command": "uv",
			"args": [
				"run",
				"--directory",
				"/Users/admin/Projects/test-mcp",
				"server.py"
			]
		}
	}
}
```

But for unclear reasons (apparently in the `settings.json` it would cause an 'ugly' `mcp->mcpServers` nesting of the keys) the `mcp.json` in VSCode uses the name `servers` instead. Would it be possible to change this or allow both? I am working on an automated installation script and the following providers are implemented without requiring any special cases:

- Claude Desktop
- Cursor
- Windsurf
- Roo Code
- Cline
- Kilo Code
- Claude Code

For clients that not yet implemented there is a `--config` option that automatically generates the JSON which also uses `mcpServers` as a key, so I would have to add a special `--vscode` flag to handle this.

Related issue https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/252907 where things were changed to match the current 'industry standard'

title: ci: address sha mismatches in unviersal build
body:
Extracted from https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/pull/261148

universal build has option to skip lipo step for mach-o files that are declared present as same arch on both packages. However it requires a sha256 comparison to ensure the files are same, currently this logic fails since we publishing the unsigned archive after the hardened entitlement step which will change file sha, this PR publishes the unsigned archive for universal step before entitlement step and additionally repackages the client after entitlement under a different name for the codesign step to make sure they aren't mixed.

```
(Pipeline.Workspace)/vscode_client_darwin_$(VSCODE_ARCH)_archive - points to archive that will be codesigned and has hardened entitlement
$(Pipeline.Workspace)/unsigned_vscode_client_darwin_$(VSCODE_ARCH)_archive - points to archive without any codesign and entitlements
```

title: render token usage
body:
Fixes https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/248860

This is a first stab at rendering token usage in Chat. Feedback is very much welcome. Open questinos:
1) Do we already have a utility that summs up all the tokens in the session (I could not find it, so I am manully implementing it in the renderer). I would love to simplify this.
2) I am not a fan of "(preview)(0x)" rendering - double brackets. Ideas on what better to do are welcome

Next steps are to colour this in some warning colour once we are above 85%. @roblourens I think that is the limit you use for summarization 

I was not convinced where to render the token usage, but after much delibaration I think showing it only on the last request actually works nicely. E.g. then it is more married to the session than to the actual request (hopefully).

Justin if you do not like the implementation let me know and I can start over - I tried to keep it minimal.

https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/12ba51df-0d42-4028-9a3e-7972ebd818a0

fyi @jo-oikawa @pierceboggan

title: Stuck in “compact → refill → repeat” loop
body:
When using the GitHub Copilot Chat VS Code extension with the **GPT-5 (preview)** model, code-change requests never complete. The session enters a loop where it **fills the context window → triggers compaction → refills → compacts again**, indefinitely. Even after raising the max request limit and letting it run for hours, **no edits are applied** to the workspace.

## Steps to Reproduce

1. Open a moderately large repo in VS Code.
2. In the Chat panel, ask the model to perform a multi-file refactor or make non-trivial code changes.
3. Observe the request sequence as the context fills, compacts, refills, and repeats.
4. (Optional) Increase the extension’s max request cap (I set it to **1000**) and run again.

## Actual Behavior

* The session cycles between “context filled” → **compaction** → “context refill” continuously.
* After **hundreds** of requests over **multiple hours**, **no edits** are applied to files.
* The loop appears to trigger when the chat context reaches \~**90k tokens** (estimate), even though **GPT-5 (preview)** supports **128k**.

## Expected Behavior

* The extension should complete a code-change request and apply edits, even on larger repos.
* Compaction should **preserve sufficient working state** so progress is made between iterations.

## Impact

* **Blocks code editing features** for larger repositories.
* Wastes API quota and time without producing changes.

## Workarounds Tried

* Increased max requests to **1000** → still loops.
* Let the session run for hours → no edits produced.

## Potential Fixes / Ideas

1. **Configurable compaction threshold**

   * Expose a setting to adjust the token budget the chat uses before compaction (e.g., allow targeting **\~120–125k** for GPT-5 128k).
   * This would help users escape the current loop on repos near the default threshold.

2. **Smarter compaction with persistent state / TODO tool**

   * Persist a compact **working plan/state** (e.g., via the new TODO tool) that survives compaction cycles.
   * The agent should remember **what was already loaded and why**, and **what’s next**, instead of re-discovering the same context each loop.

3. **Sub-agents / worker sessions with separate contexts**

   * Allow helper agents to do file discovery, symbol mapping, and research in **their own contexts**, returning **summaries/diffs** to the main session.
   * Analogy: Claude Code’s sub-agents or Roo’s **Boomerang** mode to keep the primary context lean and focused on applying edits.

title: [Bug] UI: Empty sash container remains visible after closing Side Bar in Zen Mode

labels.name: workbench-zen
labels.description: Full screen 'Zen' view issues

body:
Checkboxes (Fill these out):

[x] I have read the [guide for submitting good bug reports](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/wiki/Submitting-Bugs-and-Suggestions).

[x] I have checked the [FAQs list](https://www.google.com/search?q=https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/wiki/FAQ).

[x] I have searched the [issues](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues) to see if this problem has already been reported.

(This shows the maintainers you've done your homework.)

VS Code Version:
1.92.0-insider

Operating System:
Windows 11 Pro (23H2) (Also reproducible on macOS Sonoma 14.5)

Steps to Reproduce:
This bug can be reliably reproduced with the following steps:

Open any folder or project in VS Code.

Enter Zen Mode (View > Appearance > Zen Mode).

Open the Side Bar (e.g., the File Explorer) by clicking its icon or pressing Ctrl+B.

Close the Side Bar again by pressing Ctrl+B.

Expected Behavior:
When the Side Bar is closed in Zen Mode, it should disappear completely, leaving a clean, distraction-free view of the editor.

Actual Behavior:
When the Side Bar is closed, a thin, empty vertical bar (the sash container) is left behind on the left edge of the window. This artifact remains visible until Zen Mode is exited.

title: Add configurable shell integration timeout for terminal tools
body:
This PR adds a new configuration setting `chat.tools.terminal.shellIntegrationTimeout` to make the duration to wait for shell integration configurable in the terminal chat agent tools.

## Problem

Users reported two main issues with the hardcoded shell integration timeout:

1. **Slow shell startup in enterprise environments**: PowerShell can take 20+ seconds to start due to security software, but VS Code only waited 5 seconds, causing the "Enable shell integration" message to appear even when shell integration was working.

2. **Intentional shell integration avoidance**: Users who don't want shell integration still had to wait for the timeout, causing unnecessary delays.

## Solution

Added a new configuration setting that allows users to:
- Configure longer timeouts for slow shell startup (up to 30 seconds)
- Skip the timeout entirely by setting it to 0
- Fall back to the original hardcoded logic when not configured (preserving backward compatibility)

## Implementation

### New Configuration Setting
```json
{
  "chat.tools.terminal.shellIntegrationTimeout": {
    "type": "integer", 
    "default": 5000,
    "minimum": 0,
    "maximum": 30000
  }
}
```

### Timeout Logic
```typescript
// Get configurable timeout, fall back to original logic if not configured
const configuredTimeout = this._configurationService.getValue(TerminalChatAgentToolsSettingId.ShellIntegrationTimeout);
let waitTime: number;

if (configuredTimeout !== undefined) {
    waitTime = configuredTimeout;  // Use configured value
} else {
    // Original hardcoded logic
    waitTime = siInjectionEnabled ? 5000 : (instance.isRemote ? 3000 : 2000);
}

// Only wait if conditions are met AND timeout > 0
if ((...originalConditions...) && waitTime > 0) {
    await this._waitForShellIntegration(instance, waitTime);
}
```

## Usage Examples

**For slow PowerShell startup:**
```json
{
  "chat.tools.terminal.shellIntegrationTimeout": 25000
}
```

**To skip shell integration wait entirely:**
```json
{
  "chat.tools.terminal.shellIntegrationTimeout": 0
}
```

**Default behavior (unchanged when not configured):**
- 5000ms when shell integration is enabled
- 3000ms for remote terminals when disabled
- 2000ms for local terminals when disabled

## Backward Compatibility

Fully preserved - all existing behavior remains exactly the same when the setting is not configured. The new setting only adds capabilities without changing defaults.

Fixes #261822.

> - Add the appropriate URLs or hosts to the custom allowlist in this repository's [Copilot coding agent settings](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/settings/copilot/coding_agent) (admins only)

title: Fix OAuth2 resource parameter compliance with RFC 8707
body:
## Summary

This PR fixes VS Code's OAuth2 flow to comply with RFC 8707 by including the resource parameter in token exchange requests.

## Problem

The current implementation includes the resource indicator in the authorization request but omits it from both the authorization code and refresh token exchange requests. This violates RFC 8707 and can cause token validation failures on protected resources that require the resource parameter to be consistently present throughout the OAuth2 flow.

## Solution

Added the resource parameter to both token exchange methods in the `DynamicAuthProvider` class:
- `exchangeCodeForToken()` - now includes resource parameter when exchanging authorization code for tokens
- `exchangeRefreshTokenForToken()` - now includes resource parameter when refreshing tokens

The fix ensures that when `_resourceMetadata?.resource` is available, it is consistently included in all OAuth2 requests throughout the authentication flow.

## Test Plan

- [x] Verified the fix addresses the specific code location mentioned in #261364 (line 599 in extHostAuthentication.ts)
- [x] Ensured the resource parameter is added in both token exchange scenarios
- [x] Confirmed the implementation follows the same pattern as the existing authorization request code

Fixes #261364

title: Code reference logs appear in wrong output
body: When using code completions, I would expect to see logs recorded in the same way whether I accept a suggestion by pressing Tab or by clicking Accept. Currently by pressing Tab I see the logs in GH Copilot output and the reference in GH Copilot Log (Code References) output. However, when I click Accept on suggestion the logs appear in GH Copilot chat output instead. Please see the recording: https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/a828692d-7d91-4365-9985-a2370e7b315d **Steps to reproduce:** 1. Create a js file _quickSort.js_ 2. Start typing quick sort method: `function quickSort(arr)` 3. Wait till Next edit suggestion menu appears and click Go To/ Accept: **Expected result:** public log match log appears in GH Copilot output, code reference appears in GH Copilot Log (Code References) output, same as by accepting suggestion by pressing Tab. **Actual result:** logs appear in GH Copilot chat output instead Might be also relevant: - VS Code Version: 1.103.0 (Universal) - OS: Darwin arm64 24.6.0

title: Allow snippet nesting
body:
Currently, VS Code does not allow expanding a snippet when the cursor is inside a tab stop of an active snippet. In other editors (Sublime Text, Neovim with UltiSnips/LuaSnip), this is possible: the snippet engine permits invoking another snippet inside a placeholder, and the outer snippet continues functioning normally. 

This feature would greatly improve workflows in domains where repetitive, structured text is common, such as LaTeX, Typst, and other typesetting languages. In these cases, users often need to insert smaller “component” snippets (integrals, fractions) into math environments. At present, doing so in VS Code requires manually exiting the placeholder or invoking Trigger Suggest (`Ctrl+Space`) each time, which interrupts typing flow.

body:
As outline in [Open-source AI functionality provided by the Copilot Chat extension](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/249031) our goal is it to bring NES and completion closer together. 

As a first step we decide to port over the prompt functionality from Copilot client to Copilot Chat. The port should make use of the already existing tree sitter and tokenization libs available in chat. Based on that code we should in a next steps great an inline completion prompt that mirrors the one in Copilot client.

```
The 404 keeps going multiple times per second until I get rate limited after about 10 or 15 minutes. 

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Clone a repo down that is (in this specific case) a GitHub Free Organization, and the Repo is private.  validate that you as the user of the GH Team does not have GH Copilot on the GH team (GitHub Copilot for Business has no seats assigned).
2.Open that Repo in VS Code Insider with a GH user account that has access to that Repo (so they can commit code to that private repo) and the user gets their GH Copilot from somewhere else (I get mine from work and it is GH Copilot Enterprise). 

As a quark of where I work I have both GH Copilot Enterprise on a GH account and on an EMU account, I have tested both, and both have the same outcome... GH Copilot Chat & Authenticator flood the GH APIs to the point that it will cause rate limiting and basically kill GitHub Copilot.

title: Add bash tree-sitter grammar support for proper terminal command parsing
body:
This PR adds comprehensive bash grammar support to VS Code's tree-sitter infrastructure to enable proper shell command parsing, replacing the previous custom quote-aware implementation as requested in the feedback.

## Changes Made

**Tree-sitter Infrastructure**
- Added 'bash' to `TREESITTER_ALLOWED_SUPPORT` in TreeSitterLibraryService
- Created bash.scm query files for syntax highlighting and grammar parsing
- Added `editor.experimental.preferTreeSitter.bash` configuration option

**Terminal Command Parsing**
- Implemented actual tree-sitter parsing with proper AST traversal for bash commands
- Integrated TreeSitterLibraryService into RunInTerminalTool via dependency injection
- Added support for parsing bash nodes: `command`, `simple_command`, `pipeline`, `list`

**Robust Fallback System**
The implementation uses a tiered parsing approach:
1. **Tree-sitter parsing** (when bash WASM grammar is available)
2. **Quote-aware parsing** (handles quoted strings correctly)
3. **Legacy string splitting** (original fallback)

## Example

Commands like `echo "a|b|c"` are now properly parsed as single commands rather than being split on operators inside quotes. The system is ready to use full tree-sitter parsing once a bash grammar WASM file is added to the project.

**Backward Compatibility**: Function overloads ensure all existing code continues working without changes.

Fixes #261794.

title: Use tree sitter for terminal auto approve command parsing

labels.name: feature-request
labels.description: Request for new features or functionality

labels.name: chat-terminal
labels.description: The run in terminal tool in chat

body:
The current logic for parsing a full command line into sub-commands is a naive string splitting algorithm using the following list:

https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/blob/14978d7cc92765e69d18cbdbe02bfa8faf84aee7/src/vs/workbench/contrib/terminalContrib/chatAgentTools/browser/subCommands.ts#L17-L48

This should use a proper parser like tree-sitter to parse the command. This would fix cases like `echo "a|b|c"` being incorrectly treated as sub commands `['echo', 'a', 'b', 'c']` for example.
